history/1949-communist-takeover.html.title: 1949 Communist Takeover
history/1949-communist-takeover.html.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-05
In 1949, after the CCP won the Chinese Civil War following World War II, they were able to take over China and under the leadership of totalitarian leaders become an industrial superpower. In the Cold War, they played a crucial role in Communism in East Asia, both hindering and helping the U.S.S.R. Overall sucks to determine economic success or failure, good for everything else! What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (B) Mao Zedong's charisma was enough to pull most of the nation to his side --> as a leader, he was able to incite a massive revolution and contribute to the How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A) Takeover shows the power of peasants (e.g common people) to contribute to political change Probably the single largest event that shows how common people can contribute to political changes What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F)
This evidence just sucks, the other specific events and topics such as Land Reform were better.

history/1953-1957-first-5-year-plan.html.title: 1953-1957 First 5-year plan
history/1953-1957-first-5-year-plan.html.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-05
The first 5-year plan succeeded to help trigger industrialization in China, unlike it's successor the 1958-1962 Great Leap Forward. This was achieved by Nationalization (which was only really completed in 1955-1956), a focus on heavy industry, and sacrifices by the people of China - the standard of living was raised very little, with strict rationing that guaranteed everyone enough food to live. The entire economy was governed by a bureaucratic system run from Beijing. In the end, iron and steel production tripled, the output of coal increased from 65 million-130 million tons, and construction of dams/power plants began. Overall: (A) really good piece of evidence for EQ 1 and 3 and enough to work on EQ 2 What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A) This shows us how the CCP was extremely powerful With good administration, Mao was able to push China and start modernization extremely quickly. The entire economy was run from Beijing, which shows how political leaders can have extreme power - to have the entire economy of a country under their direct control
Nationalization shows us how governments are able to seize and take resources from the populace, which could be dangerous and shows negative change, but could also be positive change. How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (C) The success of the 5-year plan depended a lot on the workers While they were forced to obey, it shows us how having a large population was extremely helpful to China's expansion, and how the people were vital to China's success as workers What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (S)
The 5-year plan helps to show how Nationalization was able to be successful, and was a major contributing factor to economic success. The focus on heavy industry helped China become a superpower and showed the power of focused top-down centralization

history/1966-1976-cultural-revolution.ht.title: 1966-1976 Cultural Revolution
history/1966-1976-cultural-revolution.ht.description: Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-05

history/1971-china's-admittance-to-the-u.title: 1971 China's Admittance to the United Nations
history/1971-china's-admittance-to-the-u.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-06
In 1971 China was admitted to the United Nations replacing the Republic of China (Taiwan), labeled "the greatest defeat of the U.S in the history of the United Nations". Afterwards, the U.S stopped supporting the R.O.C and instead decided on it's One China Policy which tried to keep the idea of a "single China" but they stopped trying to upset the status quo. Overall: (D tier) Too much of a stretch for a lot of these What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (C) The U.S was able to give Taiwan a lot of political capital and continue to have it recognized for a long time
Afterwards, it stopped Taiwan from reentering via the One China Policy How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (F) N/A, no direct connection to people What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (C) Could argue that global acceptance of China allowed China to start becoming a world superpower, and showed how economic success allowed China to participate on the world stage might be too much of a stretch Benefited China's trade, global acceptance led to economic success

history/history.html.title: History
history/history.html.description:
#historyInfo Italicized is counter Bolded is good evidence for 2/3 EQs Highlighted is extremely good evidence for all EQs Tiers for EQ: F, you literally cannot even argue this, don't even try to use this as evidence D, very very niche, an enormous stretch if you want to use this as evidence C, a stretch but can support a specific key point B, mediocre, you could use this in your essay if you needed a filler piece or supporting piece but never your main piece A, really good evidence, able to be used in a lot of ways S, one of the essential pieces of evidence you need, without this, you can't talk about the EQ fully What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? How did people contribute to political changes in their country? What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan?
1949 Communist Takeover
1949 Taiwan Martial Law Starts
1950-1953 Korean War
1953-1957 First 5-year plan
1954 Govt. Reorganization
1956 Hundred Flowers
1956 Anti-Rightist Movement ends Hundred Flowers
1958-1962 Great Leap Forward
1959 China Takeover of Tibet
1966 Cultural Revolution Starts
1971 China's Admittance to the United Nations
==1976 Cultural Revolution Ends with the Death of Mao ==
1987 Taiwan Martial Law Ends

history/taiwan-martial-law.html.title: Taiwan Martial Law
history/taiwan-martial-law.html.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-05Martial law was enacted in Taiwan after the KMT arrival in order for the KMT to remain control, also known as the "White Terror", it was the second longest period of martial law in global history (second to Syria). However, it was decorated with massacres and protests and eventually the KMT lifted martial law in 1987. Overall: (B), mediocre, you could argue it but better pieces of evidence out there What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (B) The period of martial law serves as a way to show how CKS was extremely powerful and able to hold control over Taiwan But, it's probably better to point to Mao and the CCP's ironclad control, much stronger How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (C)
People were still willing to protest and riot, which triggered the 2/28 Incident
But still not really, martial law really doesn't show the people, just use the 2/28 Incident directly. What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F) Really difficult to truly argue this point, as it's not directly linked
e.g Nationalization, you should just argue it directly instead of arguing about martial law leading to Nationalization

math/exponents-&-logs/exponential-featur.title: Exponential Features
math/exponents-&-logs/exponential-featur.description: #math #exponents Note: These features apply to PARENT GRAPHS and change after transformations Key Point All exponential functions' parent graph has the key point (0,1) which may change with transformations Since Domain and Range D: R: Opposite of log graph Asymptotes and End Behavior All exponential functions' parent graph have a horizontal asymptote at As

math/exponents-&-logs/exponential-one-to.title: Exponential One to One
math/exponents-&-logs/exponential-one-to.description:
#math #exponents Because when by putting the same base on both sides of the equation, we can easily solve for the exponent
means , really useful when everything is a power of the same base as you can combine powers via the Exponential Properties.

math/exponents-&-logs/exponential-proper.title: Exponential Properties
math/exponents-&-logs/exponential-proper.description: #math #exponents Product Rule Quotient Rule Power of Power Note that this rule only exists for when an entire power is raised to an exponent! It does NOT exist for Negative Exponents Fractional Exponents

math/exponents-&-logs/function-compositi.title: Function Composition
math/exponents-&-logs/function-compositi.description: #math Function composition is when you set the output of one function to be equal to the input of another e.g g(f(x)) Two forms - - - both mean that you put the output of into ! There is a direction in composition! Solving - You could evaluate each function individually - Or just pass the entire function and solve the composed function - Example:

math/exponents-&-logs/graphing-exponenti.title: Graphing Exponentials
math/exponents-&-logs/graphing-exponenti.description:
#math #exponents Parent graph of all exponential functions of base is - there is no general parent graph! General note: make sure to factor your function into standard form and remove coefficients Decay functions can be treated as horizontal reflections of the parent graph Growth functions are of the form where and have an upwards curve Decay functions are where and can be treated as horizontal reflections of - Vertically reflected functions (e.g over x-axis) are NEITHER GROWTH NOR DECAY is neither growth nor decay
Exponential Features

math/exponents-&-logs/graphing-logs.html.title: Graphing Logs
math/exponents-&-logs/graphing-logs.html.description: #math #logs Logs are inverse functions of exponents Everything is just flipped! to graph inverses, just flip x and y for everything. Key Point All log functions' parent graph has the key point (1,0) which may change with transformations - Since Domain and Range R: D: Opposite of exponential graph Asymptotes and End Behavior All log functions' parent graph have a vertical asymptote at . As

math/exponents-&-logs/inverse-functions..title: Inverse Functions
math/exponents-&-logs/inverse-functions..description:
#math Inverse functions are functions which reverse the process of a given function, basically changing x and y --> this basically allows you to get your inputs back from your outputs. Inverse functions only exists for one to one functions! You must domain restrict a function if it's not one to one! Represented as Properties
The composition of the inverse and the normal function will always return the input --> if you get your inputs back from your outputs, it'll be the input again. Mathematically Domain and range flip when you invert Graphically, acts like a reflection over the line

math/exponents-&-logs/log-graph-features.title: Log Graph Features
math/exponents-&-logs/log-graph-features.description: #math #logs Key Point All log functions' parent graph has the key point (1,0) which may change with transformations - Since Domain and Range R: D: Opposite of exponential graph Asymptotes and End Behavior All log functions' parent graph have a vertical asymptote at . As

math/exponents-&-logs/log-properties.htm.title: Log Properties
math/exponents-&-logs/log-properties.htm.description: #math #logs VERY VERY IMPORTANT! YOU CAN ONLY USE THESE PROPERTIES IF and is a positive real number These rules work backwards as well to condense logs! Inverse Properties of Logs Product rule of Logarithms Quotient Rule Power Rule Change-of-Base Formula A silly mistake a lot of people make is quotient ruling this afterwards. This allows you to any log to any other log

math/exponents-&-logs/logarithmic-method.title: Logarithmic methods
math/exponents-&-logs/logarithmic-method.description:
#math #logs #exponents
When U-sub is not able to be used and the bases are different, you can take the log of both sides in order to solve the equation. When using this method, you can use ANY log Example:This is a general method but it should be your last resort. It only works when the base is isolatedYour goal is to try to reach clusters with log on one side and values on the other

math/exponents-&-logs/logs-one-to-one.ht.title: Logs One-to-One
math/exponents-&-logs/logs-one-to-one.ht.description: #logs #mathSimilar to Exponential One to One, if , This lets you solve for the antilog easily, and you set this strategy up by trying to convert both sides to the same base. Remember to check!!!

math/exponents-&-logs/rewriting-as-expon.title: Rewriting as Exponential
math/exponents-&-logs/rewriting-as-expon.description: #math #logs You can combine everything into one ginormous log and then solve by rewriting as exponential Examples soon...

math/exponents-&-logs/simplifying-expone.title: Simplifying Exponentials
math/exponents-&-logs/simplifying-expone.description:
#math #exponentsIn order to simplify an exponential No negative exponents All bases must be unique No exponent should be raised to another exponent
We can achieve this via Exponential Properties.

math/exponents-&-logs/simplifying-logari.title: Simplifying Logarithms
math/exponents-&-logs/simplifying-logari.description:
#logs #math You may be asked to condense or expand logarithms, and they have different rules to follow. Log Condensing Rules The coefficient must be 1 Rational exponents should be written in radical form Leave the input in radical form No need to rationalize! Expanding Logs No power, product, or quotient should remain in the input Numerical logs should be in simplest terms.
Evaluate logs as much as possible () Use the Log Properties to simplify logs. Note that a lot of people mess these up, make sure to take extra care when using these!An interesting problem on the last quiz involved an expression that simplified to Now, you can actually simplify this further via change of base!

math/exponents-&-logs/solving-exponentia.title: Solving Exponentials
math/exponents-&-logs/solving-exponentia.description:
#math #exponents PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER TO CHECK YOUR ANSWERS! Methods
Exponential One to One The most general method, anytime you have two exponentials to the same base you can set and solve from there. Noncheckable
U-sub Useful when you get a quadratic looking exponentials, usually of the form Checkable
Logarithmic methods - Useful when you can't solve cleanly into bases. You can use any log on an equation like to isolate x - and you can solve from there. - Checkable-ish Always check if you can use One to One, then U-sub, then logs to make it easier. The goofy example here is where you can distribute the logs to isolate, which is something you definitely want to keep in mind e.g

math/exponents-&-logs/solving-logs.html.title: Solving Logs
math/exponents-&-logs/solving-logs.html.description:
#logs #mathPLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER TO CHECK YOUR ANSWERS!
Logs One-to-One Useful anytime you only have log expressions
Changing to Exponential - Useful for everything else!
- Technically you can get here by doing Logs One-to-One by subtracting a 1-1 on both sides and simplifying... You only have two strategies: rewrite everything as two logs on both sides, or rewrite everything as the same base. Everything else won't solve cleanly. Always see if you can easily Logs One-to-One first, as it's a little bit cleaner

math/exponents-&-logs/terminology.html.title: Terminology
math/exponents-&-logs/terminology.html.description:
#math #logs #exponentsThe power is the entire expression (), and the exponent is only the value that determines how many times something is multiplied. () The base is the value that is being raised by an exponent (). e, Euler's number is an irrational number that is the limit of a function ln is the log with base e , called the natural log because of how often it appears in nature Usually, logs without bases are and called the common log But in computer science logs without bases are so don't take it for granted! Solve Leave answer as expression Solve for a variable Evaluate results in an actual value Simplify Make cleaner or more compact Pateledefinition: less operations
Logs: Condensing/Expanding
Exponential: Simplifying Exponentials In the expression , is the growth factor, it determines how fast the exponential function grows Used to determine if a function is growth or decay In exponential functions, it's in which also turns out to be the y-intercept (because )

math/exponents-&-logs/test-strategy.html.title: Test Strategy
math/exponents-&-logs/test-strategy.html.description:
Some of these are guesses, which are italicized Calculator At least one using general formulas Probably one that asks you to get the input back One intersection MCQs Conceptual understanding FRQs Testing problem solving skills Writing???? Graphing Exponents Expand to increase options then simplify U-sub to help manage your variables U-sub as soon as you see quadratic like stuff Or just condense, as long as you try to reduce the problem to make it easier reach a position where you can log, one-one, U-sub
- log -> get two clusters, one with all the powers, one with all the values and log the entire thing to isolate the exponents
- one-one -> get powers of the same base on both sides and then solve - You can't do one-one if there are any elements that are not powers, always change everything to same base if you want to use this
- U-sub -> only use when you see multiple repeated powers, especially quadratic-like equations - Useful for the simplifying step as well to make math cleaner For U-Sub, remember your equation for u is not the same as the initial variable you were solving for!!! And always check!!! Logs You only have two strategies: rewrite everything as two logs on both sides, or rewrite everything as the same base.
Logs One-to-One
Rewriting as Exponential PLEASE PLEASE CHECK LOGS, YOU ALSO NEED TO CHECK FOR U-SUB Why hard? You gonna forget that you can't do your log rules on negative logs No solution/Undefined What is the inverse function of ? Why hard? Forgetting to range restrict or Find all integer solutions for x,m Why hard? Too many ways to try to approach this at the start, approach it by trying to simplify as much as possible Recommendation: Expand first, then condense! Find the loudness of a noise that has 15 kW per square kilometer Why hard? You forget to convert the units to what the inputs were supposed to be... Transformations Always factor out the coefficients of Focus on the key point

math/exponents-&-logs/u-sub.html.title: U-sub
math/exponents-&-logs/u-sub.html.description: #math #exponentsReplace with a variable and then treat equation as a normal quadratic, e.g Make sure to solve for the actual variable and not for !!! After solving for , you need to solve for the variable again!

math/sequences-and-series/continue.html.title: Continue
math/sequences-and-series/continue.html.description: #math #sequences Continue Find the next terms If asked to find terms, write terms, not set MAKE SURE TO KNOW NOTATION AND WHAT YOU'RE SOLVING FOR Finding next term Alternating patterns via e.g if the relationship is linear, you can just plug in

math/sequences-and-series/describe.html.title: Describe
math/sequences-and-series/describe.html.description: #math #sequences Describe To describe you don't need to find next term, just say what the pattern is in ENGLISH, NO MATH Difference Subtraction/addition Terms Adjacent terms, terms next to each other Actual values in sequence Constant Never changes Ratio Multiplication/Division Term number Index of term

math/sequences-and-series/note.html.title: Note
math/sequences-and-series/note.html.description: Tags: #in-progress Date: 2025-05-08 Always look at relationship between terms because the values may be affected by transformations If no notation given anything is game Summation notation Expanded by plugging in the sequences itself with the i values Evaluate Leave upper limit Need to get summation from sequence Get sequence first and then find upper/lower limits Not this sigma , which is

math/sequences-and-series/quick-note.htm.title: Quick Note
math/sequences-and-series/quick-note.htm.description: Tags: #math #sequencies #series Date: 2025-05-06 Sequences Anything that has a pattern Formally, a number sequence is a ordered list of numbers defined by a rule. == ==The numbers of the sequence are called the terms The domain must be the set of positive numbers. List of terms with a pattern NOTE THAT 0 IS NOT INCLUDED N MUST START AT N=1 Recognize Sequences may only be evaluated at natural numbers Discrete points, not continuous curve Look for alternating signs Look for terms increasing/decreasing by common difference Look for common ratio Look for relationships via table of values Linear Quadratic Cubic Exponential Describe To describe you don't need to find next term, just say what the pattern is Difference Subtraction/addition Terms Adjacent terms, terms next to each other Actual values in sequence Constant Never changes Ratio Multiplication/Division Term number Index of term Continue Find the next terms If asked to find terms, write terms Finite Fixed amount Show end either with or just Infinite Uses ellipses that continue to nothing nth term of sequence a represent using bracket notation Make sure to have nth term at the end General term Alternating patterns via general term vs. sequence (no bracket vs. bracket)

math/sequences-and-series/recognize.html.title: Recognize
math/sequences-and-series/recognize.html.description: #math #sequences Sequences may only be evaluated at natural numbers - Discrete points, not continuous curve Look for alternating signs Look for terms increasing/decreasing by common difference Look for common ratio Look for relationships via table of values Linear Quadratic Cubic Exponential

math/sequences-and-series/terminology.ht.title: Terminology
math/sequences-and-series/terminology.ht.description: #math #sequences #series Sequence Formally, a number sequence is a ordered list of numbers defined by a rule. The numbers of the sequence are called the terms Basically a list of terms with a pattern The domain must be the set of positive natural numbers. NOTE THAT 0 IS NOT INCLUDED N MUST START AT N=1 Finite Fixed amount Show end either with or just "Finite" could end on the general term, which is still infinite Infinite Use ellipses that continue to nothing No end, sequence evaluates for all natural numbers Bracket Notation is the whole sequence when there is bracket notation Make sure to have nth term at the end General Term Without brackets is the term for any term

physics/light/angle-of-incidence.html.title: Angle of Incidence
physics/light/angle-of-incidence.html.description: #physics #lightThe angle of a ray compared with the normal (perpendicular) of any mirror line Note that it's compared to the normal, not the surface!

physics/light/angle-of-reflection.html.title: Angle of Reflection
physics/light/angle-of-reflection.html.description: #physics #lightThe angle of a reflected ray compared with the normal (perpendicular) of any mirror line. Note that it's compared to the normal, not the surface!

physics/light/concave.html.title: Concave
physics/light/concave.html.description:
#physics #light The focus is at half of the radius of the concave mirror Center of curvature is twice the focus distance, where the object looks the same size. The orientation is flipped until the object passes the focal point, but the image changes to a virtual image. Magnification is always smaller until you get closer to the focus, and because the center
Given the Mirror Equations we can show that the magnification is greater than 1 when there is a virtual image for a concave mirror only

physics/light/convex.html.title: Convex
physics/light/convex.html.description: #physics #light The focus is at half of the radius of the convex mirror Magnification is always less than one, so you always appear smaller The focus is always behind the mirror Always creates a virtual image Image is always upright (virtual image)

physics/light/law-of-reflection.html.title: Law of Reflection
physics/light/law-of-reflection.html.description: #physics #light The Angle of Incidence is equal to the Angle of Reflection of any incident ray.After reflection, the ray is called the reflected ray, and the source of the image seen (the Virtual Image) seems to come from within the mirror. Furthermore, because of this , the image distance and the viewing distance is the sameSee Lab 8-1 for the experiment to determine it

physics/light/light.html.title: Light
physics/light/light.html.description:

Concave

physics/light/light-properties.html.title: Light Properties
physics/light/light-properties.html.description:
#physics #light Spectrum of Light 462-750 Thz range in frequency Ranges of color, everyone labels it differently Newton himself created Indigo after thinking there should be 7 colors White light is just the spectrum of light combined Via refraction & a prism we can divide white light into the spectrum Refraction works via bending the light *One example of speed of wave depending on frequency is light in a medium* Purple gets bent more and red gets bent less, creating the spectrum Newton was the first to show that white light was just the entire spectrum Prisms to show the split 2nd prism correctly aligned to turn it back into white light Light is a transverse wave
Found via Polarization and vertical/horizontal filters that didn't let transverse waves through

physics/light/mirror-equations.html.title: Mirror Equations
physics/light/mirror-equations.html.description: #physics #light Focus of mirror Magnification equation - negative means that the image is inverted Mirror equation When hits the focal length, becomes infinite and thus the magnification becomes infinite, creating a projector

physics/light/observing-light.html.title: Observing Light
physics/light/observing-light.html.description: #physics #light Three ways to observe light Absorption Light is absorbed into object object is NOT that color Reflection Light reflects off object object is that color Transmission Light allowed to go through object object is that color Color cones in eyes allow us to detect light Long, medium, and short wavelengths Long (red) cone is sensitive to blue as well which lets us see purple Colorblindness Color receptors dysfunctional Monochromacy No color cones (1 in 30,000 people) Anomalous Trichromacy One color cone messed up 6.3% of men Why jard is colorblind 0.37% of women

physics/light/polarization.html.title: Polarization
physics/light/polarization.html.description:
#physics #light Polarization is when there is only a single plane of vibration
Principle behind Polaroid Filters unpolarized light scatters easily Polarized light can become unpolarized after scattering But scattering can also create polarized light! (see [[]])

physics/light/polaroid-filters.html.title: Polaroid Filters
physics/light/polaroid-filters.html.description:
#physics #light
Limit light to only one plane (Polarization) Invented by Edwin hall Broke into a physics lab after dropping out of Harvard Created using polymer acting like walls that prevent movement See figure Extremely useful for a variety of things Can fix glare after reflection, glare is typically horizontal So polaroid filter can filter all of the light and prevent it LCD screen Electrically controlled polaroid filters (Liquid Diode Crystals) that polarizes and can block or unblock specific pixels Via double polaroid filters, you can block ALL the light if you filter horizontal and vertical Light can only pass through one filter but not through both Light is polarized horizontallybut blocked by the verticalfiltersPasses through horizontal("underneath") Privacy screen 45 degree polaroid filter that splits light into components to get past the filters 3 layers of filters, middle one is 45 degrees that reorients the light Allows some light through, blocks all when the middle polaroid filter is removed The light ends up being half as intense normally First layer allows verticallight throughSecond layer allows 45 degreecomponent of light throughLast layer allows only horizontalcomponent through 3D glasses One vertical filter one horizontal filter Forces eyes to create the 3D image from two separate images Used to be color filters

physics/light/principal-focus.html.title: Principal Focus
physics/light/principal-focus.html.description: #physics #light In a Concave mirror, there is a principal focus where all of the rays converge outside of the mirrorIn a Convex mirror, the light reflects as if there is a focus within the mirrorThe principal focus is where all light rays must cross, which could mean that the rays intersect and enter the focus or the place where the rays seem to come from in a convex mirror, after the light reflects and the virtual image is always in the same place

physics/light/ray-diagram.html.title: Ray Diagram
physics/light/ray-diagram.html.description:
#physics #light Two rays emanating from a single point on the image Flat Draw one perpendicular and another that reflects off, then draw their intersection for virtual image.
Concave & Convex
==If the ray is parallel to the principal axis, it will reflect and go through the focus ==If the ray is going through the focus, it will reflect and be parallel to the principal axis
Concave is caved in One ray parallel to the principal axis which will reflect through the focus One ray through the object and principal focus which will reflect and create a ray parallel to the principal axis In the case of the object being closer than the focus, draw from the focus to the object 3 main cases Object is behind focus Object is between focus and center of curvature Object is in front of focus
Convex is facing outwards (i.e not caved in) One ray parallel to the principal axis that reflects off and seems to intersect the focus

physics/light/rayleigh-scattering.html.title: Rayleigh Scattering
physics/light/rayleigh-scattering.html.description: #physics #light Rayleigh scattering Shorter the wavelength, the more light scattered Sky is blue during day because light scattered extremely quickly thus, blue light spreads out and makes entire sky blue when sun is overhead Red at dusk because blue scatters too much Sun's ray travel the furthest through the atmosphere, only unscattered light can go through

physics/light/virtual-image.html.title: Virtual Image
physics/light/virtual-image.html.description:
#physics #light This happens when the reflected rays diverge thus making it impossible to project onto a screen A real image is able to be projected as light rays still intersect in front of the mirror The image of the object inside the mirror The reflected rays act like they are receiving light rays from the virtual image itself By viewing the virtual image, everything is identical compared to looking at the object from the same distance
Because Law of Reflection

physics/magnetism/domains.html.title: Domains
physics/magnetism/domains.html.description: #physics #magnetism Local regions in a material that are magnetically unaligned OVERALL But the individual regions' electrons are aligned! Formed with electrons pointing in the same direction to produce a net force Too random normally so the net force balances out to 0 These regions align when a magnetic field is applied to magnetize a material

physics/magnetism/electromagnets.html.title: Electromagnets
physics/magnetism/electromagnets.html.description:
#physics #magnetism #electricity
Via Induction an electric current is able to induce a magnetic field 3 ways to increase strength Increase number of coils Coils of wire are called solenoids Increase current Add a ferromagnetic core (to strengthen field)
Inside an actual magnet the domains also end up being like electromagnets!

physics/magnetism/generators.html.title: Generators
physics/magnetism/generators.html.description:
#physics #magnetism #electricity
Convert kinetic energy to electrical energy by moving a Magnet
Via Induction we know that an electric field will be generated Also works the other way around You can feed electric field to move the magnets! Becomes a motor if converting electrical energy to kinetic energy All motors are generators and vice versa!

physics/magnetism/induction.html.title: Induction
physics/magnetism/induction.html.description:
#physics #magnetism #electricity Changing magnetic fields can induce changing electric fields And changing electric fields can induce changing magnetic fields
Principle behind Electromagnets Anytime charges move you can create a magnetic field Electromagnets = moving current = moving charges = magnetic field!
Principle behind Generators Keep changing the magnetic field (by moving a magnet) and you can produce an electric field!

physics/magnetism/magnet.html.title: Magnet
physics/magnetism/magnet.html.description:
#physics #magnetism Has two poles, north and south North is negative, south is positive Field lines always go from north to south ALWAYS HAS TWO POLES, EVEN IF THE MAGNET IS SPLIT Magnetic field is strongest at the poles Unlike poles attract, north + south attract, like poles repel (north/north or south/south) Magnetic field Formed by EM waves moving back and forth (but that's AP Physics C) Field force like gravity Permanent magnet A magnet that is always "on" If split, forms two poles Temporary magnet
Magnetized via bringing a magnetic field close to it to polarize the Domains "Hard" temporary magnets are difficult to magnetize and difficult to unmagnetize Strongest ones are Neodymium magnets Conversely "soft" are easy to magnetize and easy to unmagnetize
Electromagnets Magnets formed via induction

physics/magnetism/magnetism.html.title: Magnetism
physics/magnetism/magnetism.html.description:
Right Hand Rule
Magnet
Electromagnets
Generators
Induction
Domains

physics/magnetism/right-hand-rule.html.title: Right Hand Rule
physics/magnetism/right-hand-rule.html.description: #physics #magnetism #electricity TWO RIGHT HAND RULES Force on moving charges Thumb: velocity Fingers: Magnetic field Palm: force The force is inverted for negative charges!! Parallel charges have no force (not moving across field lines) X marks are into the paper, means away Imagine it like an arrow Magnetic field around wire Point thumb in direction of velocity Direction fingers curl is direction of the magnetic field

index.html.title: index
index.html.description:
Vault for everything: MATH
PHYSICS
History

history/anti-rightist-movement.html.title: Anti-Rightist Movement
history/anti-rightist-movement.html.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-10
The campaign that Mao immediately started right after he got too much criticism after the Hundred Flowers Campaign, the persecution of everyone who criticized the government. Afterwards, if you were labeled a rightist (which stems from people who are conservative, opposite of communism) you were opposing progress. This led to the loss of intellectuals from China. This was led by Deng Xiaoping, who actually ended up going against this when he started his Economic Reform
Overall: (B+) Has to be combined with 1956 Hundred Flowers to be really powerful but it's better to use this individually than Hundred Flowers if you want to use it individually What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+) This shows how political leaders control the flow of information Mao was able to immediately restrict or relax information flow Able to show how political leaders can contribute to a lack of change How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A) This is actually really good as a counter, to show how political leaders wield so much power and control information that people can't contribute to political changes Better to use this than Hundred Flowers, as it shows how people can't criticize the government What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (B-) Led to economic failure later on as China ran out of intellectuals

history/1956-hundred-flowers.html.title: 1956 Hundred Flowers
history/1956-hundred-flowers.html.description:
Tags: #history Date of writing: 2025-05-10
The 1956 Hundred Flowers policy was a policy where Mao decided to relax censorship, thinking of the Zhou dynasty where "a hundred schools of thought" bloomed. However, Mao underestimated the amount of criticism and then led to the Anti-Rightist Movement where he hunted down those that opposed him. This led to a loss of intellectuals from China and the re-tightening of censorship.
Overall: (B) it has to be connected with the Anti-Rightist Movement to really be powerful What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A+) This shows how political leaders control the flow of information Mao was able to immediately restrict or relax information flow The Hundred Flowers program shows how political leaders have the power to control information, and thus control their population
USE WITH Anti-Rightist Movement How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (B+/A-) This is actually really good as a counter, to show how political leaders wield so much power and control information that people can't contribute to political changes
If you want to use this, please also use Anti-Rightist Movement What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (C)
Potentially good, but the much better evidence for relaxation that could lead to economic reform is Economic Reform

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the closer connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make the graph appear more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. Multiple values will be tried in order until one succeeds. Multiple values will not insert this feature multiple times.

info_includePath.description: The path on the server from which this feature can be loaded

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded
